page.title: 11FLAMBOROUGH SWORD DANCE
page.content: The sword dance is an old Flamborough tradition originally performed by a team of 8 fishermen using wooden swords. The dance was formerly done annually a few days before and after Christmas. A similar dance exists in Sweden and it is likely that the dance was brought to the village by the Vikings. The traditional clothes worn were white trousers, navy jerseys and sealskin caps. The movements of the dance were first recorded by folk dance enthusiast Cecil Sharp, when he visited Flamborough. Two fishermen returned to London with him to pass on their knowledge. The dance consists of several intricate figures. It is begun by the dancers making a star with the interlocking swords. The dance is still performed to a traditional Flamborough tune "Old Johnny Walker", a vigarous skipping step is used.
